main_forecast:
SwellCaldWell Outlook

| Day / Window (HST) | Direction (° / card.) | Period (s) | H1/3 (ft) | H1/10 est (ft) | Trend | Notes |
|---|---:|---:|---:|---:|---|---|
| 2025-10-13 21:56 | 315° (NW) | 16.7 | 8.5 | 11.1 | Peaking/arrived | Source: buoy_spectral; dominant long‑period NW energy |
| 2025-10-13 21:50 | 328° (NNW) | 15.0 | 7.5 | 9.8 | Present | Source: buoy (spectral band of NW/NNW energy) |
| 2025-10-13 21:50 | 341° (NNW) | 17.0 | 7.5 | 9.8 | Present | Source: buoy; long‑period component similar to main NW |
| 2025-10-13 21:50 | 318° (NW) | 15.0 | 7.5 | 9.8 | Present | Source: buoy — reinforcing NW quadrant energy |
| 2025-10-13 21:30 | 304° (NW) | 17.0 | 3.9 | 5.1 | Secondary | Source: buoy — lower energy, similar arrival window |
| 2025-10-13 21:56 | 000° (N) | 16.7 | 3.6 | 4.7 | Secondary | Source: buoy_spectral — narrow northerly component |
| 2025-10-13 21:30 | 168° (SSE) | 13.0 | 2.0 | 2.6 | Background | Source: buoy — small southern component / background SSW energy |

SUMMARY
- Dominant swell: long‑period NW energy (H1/3 ~8.5 ft; estimated biggest sets ~11 ft face) peaking on the evening of Mon 10/13 HST. Several NNW/NW components (7–7.5 ft H1/3, 15–17s) are concurrent and reinforcing.  
- Winds: light ENE trades observed ~070° at ~6 kt (PHNL METAR 140753Z), so winds are light and will generally not wreck north swell quality — but local variability matters.  
- Confidence: 0.7/1.0 overall. Key data gap — buoy IDs/time series for specific fetch-to‑Hawaii verification are not embedded in the digest (see DETAILS).

DETAILS
- Primary long‑period NW swell (315° / 16.7s / 8.5 ft H1/3 → ~11.1 ft H1/10): window centered 2025‑10‑13 21:56 HST in the digest. Source flagged as buoy_spectral; matches pressure/satellite analysis showing a robust WNP extratropical low with long fetch aimed toward Hawaii. Expect larger, well‑spaced sets, strong currents, and heavy impact on exposed north and northwest points. (Buoy source recorded as "buoy_spectral" in digest; specific NDBC buoy IDs unavailable — verify with NDBC buoys along 160E→180→150W great circle and local Hawaiian buoys before fielding.)  
- Reinforcing NNW/NW energy (7.5 ft H1/3 @ 15–17s): multiple spectral entries (328°, 341°, 318°) cluster around the same window; these add directional spread and longer runup on exposed reefs. They are likely from a combination of the central‑NPAC gale and the western NPAC storm complex seen on the charts. Source tags: generic "buoy" / "buoy_spectral" in digest.  
- Smaller NW components (304° / 3.9 ft @ 17s) and northerly traces (N / 3.6 ft @ 16.7s): will fill in directional variability and can make some point breaks peak/overlap — expect inconsistent sets but still substantial power at exposed reef/Pipeline lineups.  
- Southern/southeast background (SSE 168° / 2.0 ft @ 13s): minimal for the south shore — fun background groundswell but not a primary driver.  
- Tidal context: NOAA tide station 1612340 latest obs 1.34 ft at 2025‑10‑13 22:30 HST; full local tide tables needed for prime peaks — the digest tide times are limited to prior-day highs/lows, so check updated NOAA tide tables for specific spot timing.

Buoy / data note: digest lists 12/13 buoys successful and multiple spectral/buoy-derived swell components, but specific buoy IDs for the swell spectra are not included. That is a material data gap for exact arrival confirmation; operational users should pull NDBC buoy time series and WaveWatch III point data for final confirmation before paddling.

NORTH SHORE (Oahu)
- General: Expect sizable, long‑period NW swell through Mon night (10/13) into Tue (10/14), with sets capable of 10–15 ft faces on the most exposed reefs/points when H1/3 ~7–9 ft and H1/10 estimates ~10–13+ ft. Pipeline, Sunset, Ehukai and Haleiwa will see the brunt.  
- Winds: light ENE trades ~6 kt near PHNL — generally favorable for early‑morning north faces (light sideshore to light onshore depending on location). Trade gusts or local gusty bands can make shoulder/chop on exposed points. METAR PHNL 140753Z shows 07006KT; use local buoy wind obs for spot timing.  
- Hazards & surfability: heavy currents, fast‑moving long sets, and shorebreak at exposed beach entries. If the 16–17s components arrive as indicated, reef setups (Pipe, Outside Sunset) will be raw and best for experienced surfers only. Confidence in north swell timing/size moderate (0.7) — verify with local buoy spectra.  
- Tactical: incoming long‑period energy favors highest‑profile reef breaks; mid‑tide to higher tide windows will steepen faces on reefs — but check exact tide times for each break.

SOUTH SHORE (Oahu)
- General: South is quiet to small across the 13–15 Oct window. Digest shows only a minor SSE component (2.0 ft H1/3 @13s) — surf mostly background, waist‑to‑chest on favourable beach breaks. Fall climatology: south season winding down — this matches expectation.  
- Winds: E/ENE trades produce short‑period chop and small windswell on east‑facing southern points. With trades light, some clean windows possible but nothing large.  
- Tactical: good days for longboarders and less‑experienced riders at protected south beaches; not a north‑swell threat zone this window. Confidence lower for any rapid south increase (0.6) — southern hemi activity appears weak in satellite imagery.

OUTLOOK (extend 1–3 days beyond 10/13–10/15)
- Short term (10/14–10/15): NW/NNW energy should remain elevated into Tue 10/14 with gradual directional variability as central‑NPAC gales relax — expect lingering 7–9 ft H1/3 energy on the north shore early in the window, easing through 10/15. Local trade winds likely persist light to moderate; east shores see short‑period windswell.  
- Near term arrival (10/16 and beyond): a Kamchatka‑sourced prediction in the digest projects 6 ft @ 20s arriving Thu 10/16 12:51 PM HST (travel time ~2.6 days; confidence ~75%). If that arrives as forecast it will inject another long‑period NW pulse and could raise H1/3 and set‑faces again, particularly on NW exposures. This aligns with the pressure‑chart signal of a robust WNP storm capable of producing multiple long‑period arrivals over several days. Expect overlay/interference patterns (crossing seas) and potential amplification at focal points.  
- Tropical note: Central Pacific Tropical Weather Outlook shows no tropical cyclone formation expected next 7 days — no TC contribution to swell in this window.  
- Recommended checks: pull NDBC/NOAA buoy time series for open‑ocean buoys along the 160E→180→150W corridor and local Hawaiian buoys for continuous confirmation of period/height (period is the biggest control on surf face; long‑period energy will drive the big sets). The pressure charts and satellite both indicate additional long‑period NW energy is probable within 4–7 days — monitor evolution.

Final operational point
- Current digest and chart/satellite analysis paint a classic early‑fall North Shore push: long‑period NW energy is dominant now (10/13) and another long‐period node (Kamchatka 20s pulse) may arrive ~10/16 to re‑energize north exposures. Buoy ID/time series for the swell spectra are not embedded in the digest — verify with live NDBC buoy spectra and WaveWatch III output before final spot calls. Tidal station cited in digest: NOAA 1612340 (latest obs 1.34 ft @ 22:30 HST).

— Pat “SwellCaldWell” Caldwell, Surf News Network.
north_shore:
Dominant swell: a strong NW pulse — buoy reads ~8.5 ft H1/3 (≈11.1 ft H1/10 est) at ~16.7 s peaking in the window around 21:56 HST on Oct 13 — with strong supporting NNW/NW energy in the 15–17 s band that will keep the North Shore lively through the 13th and into the 14th.

Wind / tide interplay (short version): wind is light ENE (≈070° at ~6 kt in the latest METAR), which is essentially sideshore to offshore for the primary North Shore exposures and should help keep faces relatively clean during the peak periods. That light ENE is a gift with this NW/NNW energy — it will accentuate hollow, fast faces rather than mush them out. Tidal state is modest (latest water level ~1.34 ft at 22:30 HST); with these long-period swells the biggest, most critical sets will come on mid to rising tide at reef and point exposures — when the long-period energy hits shallow reefs you’ll see the biggest step-up and punch. Check your local tide table for exact high/low timing before paddling; mid/high will be the most hazardous times for impact-zone wash-through.

Flagship break notes (what to expect — read these and match skill to conditions):
- Pipeline (Ehukai) — expect long-period 16–17 s NW/NNW energy to produce fast, steep, and very hollow peaks. Faces will be powerful; occasional 1–2+ overhead barrels on the peak sets, with very little forgiveness on the inside. Offshore ENE winds should help the barrels hold but don’t be fooled — only very experienced big-wave tube riders and spotters. Exposure weight for the main NW pulse is high (~0.91–0.95), so this is a solid, direct energy source.
- Sunset Beach — long, heavy momentum on the 15–17 s band; expect powerful, lined-up sets that wind up into long rides or heavy closeouts depending on precise refraction. Big pushy takeoffs and long walls where the sand lines up; again, conditions will be raw and physical — keep an eye on transfer/shorebreak on the inside.
- Waimea Bay — with the estimated H1/10 near ~11 ft the bay will see very large, forceful sets. Waimea responds strongly to the long-period NW/NNW trains — expect heavy paddle and tow sets, significant shorewash, and big currents. This is big-water surfing; if you’re not max-confident, sit this one out.
- (Short callout) Haleiwa / Chun’s — more wind- and tide-dependent but expect solid overhead+ sets at exposed points; cleaner in the morning with the light ENE.

Hazards: this energy sits at or just below many seasonal High Surf Advisory thresholds for the North Shore (H1/10 ~11 ft estimated). That means hazardous shorebreaks, strong rip currents, wash-throughs over reef flats, and heavy impact zones at the main breaks — serious consequence for wipeouts. If you plan to surf, use flotation, have spotters, and respect watercraft/tow safety protocols. Lifeguard advisories and beach closures are possible if heights verify or if local bathymetry combines to produce larger-than-expected faces.

Confidence and uncertainties: overall data coverage is good (12 of 13 buoys online, charts/sat/tides successful); global confidence is moderate (0.69/1.0) and the North Shore quality index here is roughly 0.56. I’m confident the NW 16–17 s train will be the dominant driver and that exposed NW/NNW breaks will feel it strongly (exposure weights for the main NW/NNW drivers are high ~0.91–0.95). Uncertainty is moderate around the exact peak set timing at individual breaks and the relative contribution of the several similar-direction components (some NNW 17 s pieces have lower weights ~0.50), so expect variability by beach and tide. Also watch for the next Kamchatka pulse (model/track suggests 6 ft @ 20 s arriving ~Oct 16 at ~12:51 PM HST, 75% confidence) that could refresh or amplify the long-period background after the 15th.
south_shore:
South Shore forecast — Oct 13 → Oct 15, 2025
Confidence: medium (0.69). Data basis: 12/13 buoys, full chart/satellite/tide/metar coverage. Forecast focuses on actual SSE energy measured at the South Shore plus the strong northern-hemisphere background that can “wrap” into exposed town reefs.

1) Opening assessment — size, direction, timing
- Primary South energy: SSE ~2.0 ft H1/3 (≈2.6 ft H1/10) at ~13 s — measured window around Oct 13 evening (21:30 HST). That is the only direct south component of note for the period; expect small, slow south-swell lines through Oct 13–15.
- Background/wrap risk: Large long-period NW/NNW energy is dominant offshore (multiple buoy reports centered 15–17 s; strongest analysis ~8.5 ft H1/3 ≈ 11.1 ft H1/10 at ~16.7 s). That energy will be the controlling factor for overall sea state offshore and can refract/diffract into south-facing, less-sheltered reefs — especially during the NW peaks late Oct 13 into Oct 14. Expect the overall sea to be confused: small true south sets interlaced with longer, infrequent, steeper NW sets where local bathymetry allows wrap.
- Timing: Small SSE component is present now and holds through Oct 15 but stays in the 2 ft H1/3 class. The long-period NW energy is already in the water column (Oct 13) and should be strongest through Oct 13–14 before gradually fading into Oct 15. A separate longer-period storm from Kamchatka is modeled to arrive after our window (Oct 16).

2) Town vs outlier breaks (Ala Moana, Waikiki, Diamond Head) — tides & winds
- Winds: latest METAR 070° at 6 kt (light ENE). Expect light trades (E–ENE) through the window — generally under 10 kt. That wind vector gives a mild quartering onshore for true south exposures (creates a touch of bump at many South Shore spots) but is light enough that mornings should be reasonably clean.
- Tides: tidal range is modest; latest obs ~1.3 ft (Oct 13 late). With small south energy, tide will modulate shape more than size — mid to higher tides will soften reef breaks; lowest tides tend to focus energy on shallow reefs.
- Ala Moana (Bowls/Harbor): well protected from NW. With the measured SSE ~2 ft you’ll see knee-to-waist high, most consistent midtide. Ala Moana tends to be mushy on small periods; expect mellow rides good for longboard cruising and small-board practice. Wraped NW energy is unlikely to materially increase size here.
- Waikiki (Canoes/Queens/Pops): small SSE at ~13 s is the ticket — longboard/open-face rides on the peak sets. Light ENE winds make it rideable early; bump builds later day. Waikiki will be the consistent, forgiving option for most surfers over the three days.
- Diamond Head / Paddlers & Reef points east of Waikiki: most likely to register any NW wrap. Because these points have more exposure and reef contours that can refract long-period NW energy, expect occasional bigger, steeper sets late Oct 13 into Oct 14 (chest–head high+ on the face at times if refraction lines up). These larger sets will be inconsistent and accompanied by mixed-period confusion; they favor shortboard maneuvering when they occur.
- Outliers (east point reefs / Sandy’s / Kaimana stretch): respond best to true SSE/S windswell — with only ~2 ft H1/3 they’ll be small but clean for longboarders at low to mid tide. Outliers that are more exposed to NW will show the wrap-enhanced sets described above.

3) Longboard vs shortboard suitability, crowd & consistency expectations
- Longboards: best play across the period. The measured SSE 13 s energy (2 ft H1/3) produces slow, softer lines ideal for noseriding — Waikiki and Ala Moana will be the most consistent longboard options. Expect long, mellow rides during the better windows.
- Shortboards: will see payoff if/when the NW long-period sets refract into exposed reef zones (mainly Diamond Head and some east reefs). Those sets will be steeper and faster but inconsistent and generally interspersed with small, messy south-swell lines. Shortboard sessions will be more hit-or-miss and require patience.
- Crowds/consistency: Overall small, mellow south-swell → lower-to-moderate crowds at main town breaks (Waikiki/Ala Moana). Diamond Head and the exposed outliers will attract small numbers of experienced surfers willing to sit through lulls for the occasional better NW-wrapped set.

4) Wrap potential & physics note
- Wrap is the key story. Deep-water analysis shows substantial long-period NW energy (15–17 s, H1/3 7–8.5 ft; H1/10 up to ~11 ft). Islands and reef geometry will refract/diffract a portion of that energy into south-facing reefs. Expect the wrap to be:
  - Most effective at reef points with clear refractive corridors (Diamond Head, some east-side reef passes).
  - Moderately effective elsewhere — Ala Moana and most of Waikiki will remain dominated by the direct SSE 2 ft component and are largely protected from the full NW pulse.
  - Intermittent in timing — long-period NW sets will come in low frequency (long intervals), produce steeper faces when they do, then lapse back to the small SSE rhythm.
- Practical expectations: where wrap lines build, faces can run chest–head+ at peak sets (H1/3 estimates 3–5 ft locally); where protected, expect the measured SSE ~2 ft H1/3 (≈2.6 ft H1/10) with long, soft faces.
- Physics-based outlook: a separate far-northern storm (modeled Kamchatka event) is projected to arrive Oct 16 (6 ft @ 20 s), which could amplify northwest energy after our 3-day window — keep an eye on Friday for a more organized northern pulse.

Confidence statement and data completeness
- Confidence: medium (0.69). Buoy coverage strong (12/13), charts/satellite/tides/METAR all available and consistent. The main uncertainty is how much of the large NW energy will refract into specific south reef corridors — local bathymetry and small-angle refraction create spotty, high-variance outcomes. Expect clean, small south conditions for longboarders in town; expect occasional, steeper NW-wrapped sets at exposed reefs with higher shortboard potential but more inconsistency.

Bottom line: Friday–Sunday (Oct 13–15) is a mellow South Shore window overall — best for longboards and cruisy sessions (Waikiki, Ala Moana). Keep an eye on Diamond Head and east reef passes for intermittent long-period NW sets that will be steeper and faster; those are higher-skill, lower-frequency opportunities. Watch for increased NW energy after Oct 15 with the modeled Kamchatka arrival on Oct 16.
daily:
HEADLINE: Big long‑period NW energy on the North Shore — heavy, powerful and for experienced chargers only; South Shore tiny and clean.

NORTH SHORE: Faces: NW–N; swell: dominant NW ~16–17s (H1/3 ~8.5 ft; H1/10 est ~11 ft) — expect very large, fast sets at exposed breaks; best window: today mid‑afternoon into evening (swell already in and holding) — extreme caution, expect heavy shorebreak, strong currents and big reef/paddleouts.

SOUTH SHORE: Faces: S–SSE; swell: small SSE ~2 ft @13s — waist‑to‑chest at protected beach breaks; best window: morning→midday when winds stay light; not worthwhile at exposed south reefs.

EAST / WEST quick hits:
- EAST: Light ENE winds give generally clean, small surf for east-facing breaks — good for SUP/longboard.
- WEST: Minimal energy; small and inconsistent — OK for beginners at protected spots.

WINDS: METAR PHNL 070° at 6 kt (light ENE trades). Winds are light enough to keep north and east exposures relatively clean; expect light cross‑shore at some inside Waikiki breaks but nothing gusty. Conditions should stay under ~10 kt today.

TIDES: Latest obs 10/13 22:30 HST = 1.34 ft (tide running low‑moderate). (Note: recent high/low reference: 10/12 high ~2.20 ft, low ~0.21 ft.) Check NOAA station 1612340 for exact high/low times before you go.

ACTION ITEM: If you’re not comfortable in large, long‑period NW surf with big currents and reef/paddle hazards — do not go. Experts: pick an established big‑wave spot with water patrol, aim for mid→high tide this afternoon/evening when shape will be most consistent. Casual surfers/learners: stay on the south/east protected breaks this morning.

summary_lines: Confidence up 0.00 since the previous run.
